column1: Port Stephens Council (also known simply as Port Stephens) is a local government area in the Hunter Region of New South Wales
column2: Australia. The area is just north of Newcastle and is adjacent to the Pacific Highway which runs through Raymond Terrace
column3: the largest town and Council seat. The area is named after Port Stephens
column4: which is the major geographical feature of the area. It extends generally from the Hunter River in the south
column5: to near Clarence Town in the north
column6: and from the Tasman Sea in the east
column7: to just south of Paterson in the west. The mayor of Port Stephens Council is Ryan Palmer. Port Stephens is about two and a half hours north of Sydney.

column1: Most of the population is concentrated in Raymond Terrace and its satellite suburb of Heatherbrae or around or near the shores of Port Stephens in the suburbs of Anna Bay
column16: Tanilba Bay and Taylors Beach. However
column17: another significant portion of the population lives in a large rural/semi-rural area to the west of the Pacific Highway in the towns and suburbs of Balickera
column27: Wallalong and Woodville and in the predominantly residential estate of Brandy Hill.

column1: In the southern part of the area are the rural communities of Bobs Farm
column5: Tomago and Williamtown. Tomago supports both rural and industrial communities while Williamtown is the location for a Royal Australian Air Force base that shares its airfield with Newcastle Airport.

column1: At the northern end of the area are Karuah and Twelve Mile Creek. Located adjacent to Port Stephens and straddling the Karuah River
column2: Karuah is predominantly residential. It is the location of the largest Aboriginal community in the area. Twelve Mile Creek is almost exclusively rural.
between Raymond Terrace and Port Stephens are Campvale
column3: Ferodale and Medowie. Ferodale is dominated by Grahamstown Dam
column4: a man-made dam with a capacity of 131
column6: 650×10^6 cu ft) that is a major source of fresh water in the region. The remainder of this area is a mix of rural

column3: 807 people in the Port Stephens local government area
column4: of these 49.2 per cent were male and 50.8 per cent were female. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people made up 3.6 per cent of the population
column5: which was higher than the national and state averages of 2.5 per cent. The median age of people in the Port Stephens Council area was 42 years
column6: which was significantly higher than the national median of 37 years. Children aged 0 – 14 years made up 19.5 per cent of the population and people aged 65 years and over made up 19.3 per cent of the population. Of people in the area aged 15 years and over
column7: 52.0 per cent were married and 13.5 per cent were either divorced or separated.Population growth in the Port Stephens Council area between the 2001 census and the 2006 census was 7.10 per cent; and in the subsequent five years to the 2011 census
column8: population growth was 7.15 per cent. When compared with total population growth of Australia for the same periods
column9: being 5.78 per cent and 8.32 per cent respectively
column10: population growth in the Port Stephens local government area was approximately equal to the national average. The median weekly income for residents within the Port Stephens Council area was significantly lower than the national average.At the 2011 census
column11: the proportion of residents in the Port Stephens local government area who stated their ancestry as Australian or Anglo-Celtic exceeded 81 per cent of all residents (national average was 65.2 per cent). In excess of 63% of all residents in the Port Stephens Council nominated a religious affiliation with Christianity at the 2011 census
column12: which was significantly higher than the national average of 50.2 per cent. Meanwhile
column15: households in the Port Stephens local government area had a significantly lower than average proportion (4.6 per cent) where two or more languages are spoken (national average was 20.4 per cent); and a significantly higher proportion (92.2 per cent) where English only was spoken at home (national average was 76.8 per cent).

column1: Port Stephens Council is composed of ten councillors
column3: for a fixed four-year term of office. The Mayor is directly elected while the nine other Councillors are elected proportionally as three separate wards
column4: each electing three Councillors. The most recent election was held on 9 September 2017

column1: A 2015 review of local government boundaries by the NSW Government Independent Pricing and Regulatory Tribunal recommended the merger of a number of adjoining councils. In the initial proposal
column2: Port Stephens Council was not included in any amalgamation proposals. However
column3: after Lake Macquarie City Council successfully avoided a proposed merger between it and Newcastle City Council
column4: the Minister for Local Government subsequently proposed that Newcastle City Council instead merge with Port Stephens Council to form a new council with an area of 1
column5: 045 km2 (403 sq mi) and support a population of approximately 230
column6: 000.The proposed merger was met with significant opposition. Thousands of residents attended rallies and signed petitions opposed to the proposal
column7: while 470 attended public inquiry meetings. The state member for Port Stephens
column9: former state member Craig Baumann and broadcaster Alan Jones all publicly expressed their opposition. Federal Liberal member for Paterson
column12: urging the Liberal Baird government to reconsider the proposal
column13: claiming "this proposal seems to defy logic". Port Stephens Council claimed that 93% of residents surveyed were opposed to the merger and included the results of its community survey in its submission to the delegate responsible for evaluating the merger. In response to the government's proposal
column14: Port Stephens Council formally asked the government to evaluate a merger between Port Stephens and Dungog Shire. Although the mayor of Dungog Shire opposed the merger
column15: it was reported that the proposal had community support within both local government areas. The proposal was debated in the New South Wales parliament on 23 March 2016
column16: with the Minister for Local Government confirming that the proposal had been referred to the Office of Local Government.On 14 February 2017
column17: the NSW government announced it would not be proceeding with further regional council mergers
column18: including the Newcastle City Council and Port Stephens Council merger.

column1: Port Stephens Coaches operates bus services in Port Stephens. It also provides services to Newcastle (terminating at Newcastle station) and between Newcastle and Newcastle Airport. Port Stephens Coaches also runs a daily coach service to Sydney
column2: terminating at Central railway station.Newcastle Airport
column4: is the located in the Port Stephens suburb of Williamtown. It is the 12th busiest airport in Australia. The airport has direct flights to Brisbane
column10: Sydney and Taree. It is served by Virgin Australia
column13: Jetstar and Regional Express.Although Hexham railway station is closer
column14: Newcastle Interchange is the nearest major railway station to Port Stephens. NSW TrainLink operates services from here to Sydney Central station
column18: Muswellbrook & Scone. The station is served by the Central Coast & Newcastle Line and the Hunter Line.Port Stephens Ferry Service provides a ferry link between Nelson Bay and Tea Gardens.

column1: Port Stephens Council covers an area of 979 square kilometres (378 sq mi)
column2: stretching approximately 57 kilometres (35 mi) from east to west and approximately 30 km (19 mi) from north to south
column3: and experiences various climatic conditions throughout the LGA. These are monitored by five weather stations
column4: four of which are located at the approximate cardinal points of the area
column5: operated by the Bureau of Meteorology. The fifth station is located on RAAF Base Williamtown. The following tables indicate average climatic data throughout the area.
